Tertullien's view was that of the African Ohmch, end in particular that of the Metropolitan Ohurch of Carthaga. The same practice was observed by the Ohurchse of Syria and of Asia Minor. This was not the case, however, at Rome and Alexandria In these two great Ohnrohes, and in those following their direction, a distinction was made. Baptism with water was admitted to be valid, whoever had administered it and in whatever sect it had been oan- lamed, so long as the essential forms had been observed As to the remaining part of the initiation, it was rejected, and had therefore to be repeated in the case of the heretic who demanded entrance into the Ohurch.

In the year 256, the divergence between the African and Roman practice was the cause of an animated discussion between Pope Stephon and st. Cyprian, Bishop of Carthage ; but the conflicting customs‚ notwithstanding, remained un· modified It was not until the Council of Arles, in 314, that the Catholic Ohurch in Africa gave up her ancient practice.¹ It was, nevertheless, obstinetely persisted in by the Donatista, who even applied it to the Catholic Ghuroh, which was treated by them as a dissentient sect. The Eastern Churoh also continued to regard the baptism of heretice as invalid.² Distinctions, however, econ came to be introduced.
